Fields.DialogueText: Yūbari? Yūbari!
Yes, Kanchou?
We're about to leave port. Is everything ready to go?
Hai! I've carried out the last of the inspections. All that's left is... my quarters! And here we are.
They're...
I pride myself on being a light traveler, Kanchou. I'll be fine.
Except for the trunk there at the foot of your bed. Why is the lid tied down?
Lots of clothes. Ready to make way?

Fields.MenuText: Yūbari, I've only ever seen you wearing that one outfit.

Fields.DialogueText: If you're looking for a fashion plate, talk to Kongou. All I need for a fight is gunpowder dust on my cheeks and the east wind at my back.
Courage. Passion. The ability to take a punch and keep going.
@BATTLE
Verging on spartan. You don't have much in the way of personal belongings, Yūbari. Are you sure you have everything you'll need out on the high seas?
Impeccable?
You paint a rugged picture, Yūbari.
Mochiron! You gotta have grit to survive out here.
Grit?
I see. Sort of like a cowboy.
When a twister throws a horse your way, you roll with it and come up mounted!
I don't think cowboys actually did that.
But they could have! That's what's important.
Let's put that grit to use against the Morganas.
After I'm done with them, they'll be scrubbing it off their decks for weeks!

Fields.MenuText: You're not stashing any contraband, are you?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, Kanchou! If I had any lost Aztec gold, you know I'd share it with you. We'd blow from port to port leaving coins in our wake like prairie dust.

Fields.MenuText: Why don't you tell me what's really in that box?

Fields.DialogueText: Personal things! It's a rough-and-tumble ocean out there. A lady has to have a secret or two squirreled away where bandits can't see.
Stick 'em high!
Aaa! You frightened me, Yūbari.
You have to be ready for anything, Kanchou. The enemy could come at any time.
That's what we've got the lookouts for.
Ah, so you think you're clever, do you?

Fields.MenuText: I wouldn't have made captain if I weren't.
Well, I'd like to think I'm reasonably intelligent.
What do you mean?

Fields.DialogueText: Plenty of city slickers stumble into things they can't stumble out of.
I suppose you would never have made kanchou if you didn't have some smarts.
Don't get clever with me, Kanchou. I'm not out here to save frogs that thought they could swim in the Pacific.
Please, just don't jump out and scare anyone anymore. I already heard complaints from other soldiers. You're putting them on edge.
Well, out on the open waters, everyone has to be tough. Vigilant. You never know what may happen.
*ALARM*
Just like that.
We're going to have to talk about your curious timing.
@BATTLE
Curiously flawless?
In a sense.
I swear, the sun is out to get me today. I need a hat like yours, Yūbari.
Oh, this old thing?
I made it myself. I styled it after the hats worn by American cowboys. What do you think?

Fields.MenuText: I love it. It looks great on you.
The brim provides so much shade, it must be useful in times like these.
Don't you think it's a tad silly?

Fields.DialogueText: Arigatō! There's something real cavalier about this style.
Not to mention, I can also use the brim to avoid making eye contact with Funayūrei. Useful, indeed, not to mention intimidating.
Silly? Kanchou, cowboys are like the sailors of the plains. They're my idols.
You're pretty committed to that look of yours, aren't you?
I'm going to have to fit in if I want to visit the American west one day.
That's a good goal to have, Yūbari. But I don't think they dress like that anymore.
We'll just see about that! Once we win this war I'll show you who dresses how.
Speaking of war, I think the Morganas have been sighted nearby.
Let's race over there and show them who's boss.
Whoa, there! Slow down. We'll reach them soon enough.
@BATTLE
Where did you get it? Or is it just a Belle thing?
Ahh, the fresh smell of coffee. Nothing beats it. I love that rich aroma. It smells like paradise.
... Yūbari?
Sumimasen. I didn't realize you were here.
Yūbari, we're in the middle of a strategy meeting. You were supposed to be here half an hour ago.
Hold on, hold on, let me have my coffee first.
Isn't it a little late for coffee?
It's never late for coffee.

Fields.MenuText: How do you drink it black?
You're going to be bouncing off the walls.
There's no substitute for punctuality.

Fields.DialogueText: I prefer a drink with a rich, full taste. It can't be contaminated with milk or creamer or sugar.
This is how I get my energy, Kanchou. You want me at my best, don't you?
Oh, don't be so mulish. You've got to be resourceful out here. Coffee is a resource.
Could you sit down so we can continue with the meeting?
Sure. Go right ahead.
*ALARM*
No time for meetings, Kanchou. The Funayūrei are waiting!
@BATTLE
Why do I even bother?
You never give up, Kanchou. That's half the battle!
Kanchou? Kanchou? Kanchou? Kanchou? What are you up to? What are you doing? Anything interesting?
See, this is why you shouldn't drink three cups of coffee at once.
Oh, please. I'm fine. That was just my morning coffee.

Fields.MenuText: You're clearly not fine.
You can take it down a notch.
And your afternoon coffee, and your evening coffee.

Fields.DialogueText: Kanchou, I'm fine. Maybe I'm a little hyper. But it's good for the ship, I swear!
Kanchou, as long as I'm in tip-top fighting shape, I think I can do what I want.
Not a chance! This stuff will wear off within the hour.
Yūbari, are you certain you can function in battle like this?
Kanchou, don't doubt my skills. I know what I'm capable of.
It's not your skills I'm worried about.
Good! Hey, look, there are some Funayūrei on the horizon. I'm glad we've got 'em in our sights. Are you glad? Eh? Eh?
Yūbari, the whole ship is vibrating.
Aw, that's just the call of frontier justice rustling me up for a fight!
Yūbari, maybe we should switch you over to decaf...
@BATTLE
We've received a message.
What's this? Let me read it.
Hey! Don't snatch that away from me.
Can't keep justice in the dark. Heh! What have we here...?
Well, it looks like there's a ship in distress nearby.

Fields.MenuText: Let's get after them. They could be in trouble.
What do you think?

Fields.DialogueText: Right, we have to figure out some way to help those in need. That's what heroes do!
I think we should go help them. If we're not helping the innocent, what are we out here for?
I don't disagree.
It won't take us long to reach the distressed ship. We might even run into some Funayūrei on the way!
Let's proceed and scout the location. You might find that adventure you're always in search of.
Looks like the adventure's found us!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: It could be a trap.

Fields.DialogueText: Then we'd better trap the trappers!
Why didn't we get a signal?
Radio's down. One of the picket ships saw their signal flags.
*ALARM*
According to these coordinates, we shouldn't be too far from the distressed ship.
I don't see anything yet.
I'm not sure how a ship could have found themselves in trouble out here. It's peaceful and flat as far as the eye can see.

Fields.MenuText: Not everyone is meant for traveling the seas.
Maybe they had some kind of mechanical failure.
The Funayūrei must have found them.

Fields.DialogueText: When you're out here, you must be strong. And tough. It's the way of the ocean, Kanchou.
Don't go out riding on a limping mare. That's just common knowledge.
If so, it's a wonder their ship is still afloat. Maybe they've got grit after all.
Don't worry, Yūbari. We'll find them soon. And when we do, we'll find out what happened.
Well, until then, I'm going to lay out in the sun. We're going to need all the rest we can get.
Why's that?
The Funayūrei are coming. I can smell 'em.
I imagine that they don't smell good.
They smell like charred human remains. I hear they sometimes wear the uniforms of the people they kill.
Maybe they're not literally true, but every legend starts somewhere. We're dealing with varmints among varmints, Kanchou.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
I don't think stories like that really help.
Kuso! Who else but the Funayūrei  could hide in plain sight?
What are you thinking about, Yūbari?
Life and death. Good and evil. What it all means. What we're really out here for.
Complex thoughts, to be sure.
If I think about it too long, I get the sudden urge to sail off, for just a while at least, and see what else these seas have to offer.

Fields.MenuText: Being in the Imperial Japanese Navy is definitely one way to do that.
You think you could strike out on your own?
We've got an obligation to the Fleet.

Fields.DialogueText: Yeah, I know the waters controlled by the Empire of Japan well. But as many battles as we win, there's just so much more ocean left to see.
It would be pretty fun. It's easier with the Navy behind me, but I'm sure we'll make plenty of friends along the way.
Don't let that obligation burn out your sense of adventure.
War brings the world together, in a weird way.
Especially if you're a Kami. Of course, I know whose waters would be on the top of my list...
Oh, really?
The United States of America, of course.
Ah, that's not surprising.
I know. But to be that close to real cowboys... what a thrill that would be!
I think those days are over.
Well, keep going west and eventually you get to Japan. Now who's the real cowgirl?
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Yūbari, you need to get up. We have business to attend to.
I'm coming, I'm coming. Where's the coffee?
Right here.
Ahh, that tastes good. None for you?

Fields.MenuText: Don't like it. Don't need it.
I already had mine.
None for me right now.

Fields.DialogueText: I forgot. You must be one of those "tea" people. Yuck. I'm pretty all right with being the odd Kami out.
You look pretty energized. Try and keep up, then, okay?
I can't get anything done without a cup of coffee. How are you alive right now?
Once you're done with your coffee, join me on the bridge.
Have we found some Funayūrei?
Yes, and that's not all. We've located the distressed ship.
Point me in the right direction. I'm ready to go!
@BATTLE
Now that those Funayūrei are out of the way, what's next?
The ship was barely afloat, and it appears as if those on board abandoned ship some time ago.
We can take a damn good crack at it.
Sounds like a rescue mission to me. What are we waiting for, then?

Fields.MenuText: Here's that adventure you were looking for.
I wonder what we'll find?
It's a mission like any other. Don't expect anything grand.

Fields.DialogueText: It's the wild, wild sea, and we're just two renegade sailors offering aid to those in need.
Who knows, Kanchou? But with the two of us working together, I'm sure it will be great.
Why not? I bet we'll come face to face with all sorts of savage Funayūrei.
Any concerns?
Only that there won't be enough Funayūrei for us to fight.
That's not really what I meant.
*ALARM*
A little inspiration never hurts!
@BATTLE
Have we searched the waters top to bottom?
At times like these I ask myself what Dave King would do.
Who?
From King of the Royal Mounted! This would be just another walk in the Rockies for an intrepid corporal like him.
I'm not really one for adventure stories. We get enough excitement out here.
I don't think those who abandoned ship made it any further than this, Kanchou.
Look at the waters. There's debris everywhere.
I see it.

Fields.MenuText: We're too late.
Are there any survivors?
They won't get away with this.

Fields.DialogueText: If only we'd gotten here faster.
It doesn't look promising, Kanchou.
We always get our man, Kanchou. This time will be no different.
Yūbari, you don't seem shocked by any of this.
Their deaths are a shame, but this is what happens when the unprepared venture out into these seas.
Yūbari, show a little compassion.
What will compassion gain the dead, Kanchou?
Then show some respect, at least. Respect for the dead is common to both Japanese and American West culture, is it not?
We have a responsibility to track down the outlaws that did this and bring them to justice. That's pretty respectful in my book.
*ALARM*
Looks like they're doing half our work for us.
@BATTLE
Then let's meet them halfway!
In the wild, we must ensure nothing is tougher than we are.
You know, this war is about more than who's toughest, Yūbari.
Sure about that? Consider cowboys. There's a reason no one messes with them. If anyone's got grit...
Yūbari, that's not entirely accurate.
What do you mean, Kanchou?

Fields.MenuText: The cowboys weren't invincible.
I'll admit, cowboys had grit.
They're not what you think they are.

Fields.DialogueText: Hai. Outlaws, Indians, even mountain lions... the wild West is full of dangers. Not everyone's up to the challenge.
Well, of course they did. But what are you trying to get at?
What do you mean? They won the West!
The cowboys you're thinking of no longer exist.
What? O-of course they do.
No, they don't. Fifty years ago, maybe. But those long cattle drives across the open plains have come to an end.
Ha... ha. Great joke, Kanchou.
I'm not joking, Yūbari. I'm as serious as...
You're such a kidder. I'm going to remember you once the war is over.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
... as a Morgana attack.
I wasn't joking earlier, Yūbari. The Old West has ceased to exist.
But what about the stories of bandits and gunslingers? There are new ones every week!
They're just stories. Fantasy. And most of what they depict never really existed in the first place.
Kanchou, I shaped my entire life around this. My clothes... my hat!
There's nothing wrong with your hat, Yūbari.
How could you tell me this?

Fields.MenuText: I never meant to hurt your feelings.
I was just telling you the truth.
I just wanted you to understand that the cowboys weren't invincible.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, mission not accomplished. Why even go to America if it's not the one that inspired me?
In the most insensitive way possible.
There must have been a better way of doing it, Kanchou.
I'm sorry, Yūbari. I should have put more thought into my words.
It's a little late for that. Why bother ever going to the American West? Why bother riding horses? I should just go back to Japan.
No need to do that. And horseback riding isn't just for cowboys.
*ALARM*
Forget it, Kanchou. Now, let's go fight the Funayūrei. I need to take my anger out on something.
@BATTLE
I guess they were just all... stories.
Hey, Yūbari. Just reading?
I thought I'd crack open the trunk and dive back into the stories that really matter.
That's quite the pile of cowboy comics magazines. Western Picture Stories, Buckskin Jim, Star Ranger...
You may say they're for kids, but I think escapism can be useful, especially in a war like this. Do you understand what I mean?

Fields.MenuText: Of course. I used to read comics too.
I think I understand. Life can imitate art.
No, I don't read comic books.

Fields.DialogueText: They're a window into an entirely different world... one I wanted to believe in.
I should understand that better than most. But it's the other way around. These were drawn because it's what the artists wanted to see.
Maybe you should. Maybe everyone should. They tell us things you can't always communicate just by talking.
It's not your fault.
You're not to blame. I am... for not doing what I knew had to be done.
*ALARM*
I suppose it's that time, isn't it?
You can still go to America when this is over. Even if Dave King isn't real, the rugged wilderness he lives in is.
@BATTLE
Good people, Kanchou. Adventurous sorts who know how to live off the land and always get their man, try as he might to disappear into the untamed frontier.
Only think about Dave King. He goes where most can't and does what most won't, because it's right.
I just... wanted to believe there was somewhere where people did.
Isn't that what we should be doing? Couldn't we have saved that ship if we'd set off just a bit sooner, when we knew we had to?
Oh, what do you know, Kanchou? Dave King is Canadian anyway.
Kanchou, you're here. Good.
Is that just because I'm a spectacular conversationalist, or...?
I think I spotted a scout a moment ago. If I did-
Right. Sound the alarm and see if you can trace the thing back to its master.
Preferably before they can organize an air strike.
Hai!
@BATTLE
We had a good battle. Those Funayūrei were driven straight back.
Good job, team. Just as directed.
Hmm? You are usually more excited after battles, Yūbari.
I suppose I just haven't been very into them, lately.
We're at war. You have a duty to stand and fight.
I know, I know. I'll do what you ask of me.

Fields.MenuText: We need to find your spark again.
Yūbari, you need to get over yourself.
What can I do for you?

Fields.DialogueText: Dust in the wind, Kanchou. Just like the thing that sparked it.
Get over myself? Really, Kanchou? That's very inconsiderate of you.
Help me find something new to believe in, Kanchou.
All right, all right. Right now, though, the Morganas are retreating, and we need to tail them.
It could be a feint.
We'll leave that for the-
For the authorities to decide, right. No matter how wrong they may be.
@BATTLE
Hey, Yūbari, look what I've got for you. Some melon.
I'm not in the mood for it. You can find someone who is.

Fields.MenuText: That's rude, Yūbari.
I was just trying to be nice.
This sort of fruit is rare in these parts, you know?

Fields.DialogueText: I know, and I'm sorry. I'd prefer to be alone right now.
I know you were, Kanchou. But that's not important right now.
I do. But that doesn't mean I'm hungry.
I'll just leave it here. Have fun with your comics.
Have fun with the Funayūrei.
Will you join us when they come?
Yūbari?
I'll fight. Not because Command or the Navy says I should. Because it's what I'm built for. The battles they pick are on their conscience.
Good to hear it. See you on the bridge.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
This war would be over in a year if they'd just... ugh.
*ALARM*
We'll be in firing range soon, Kanchou.
Looking forward to it.
@BATTLE
It's nice to see you up and about. Typically you take a break after battles.
I'm as surprised as you are. I'm on the hunt for coffee.
Come on, stay a little bit. We haven't spent any time together for a while now.
You... could have a cup of coffee with me, if you'd like.
Sure.
Milk and sugar?

Fields.MenuText: Yes. Lots.
A little of both.
None for me.

Fields.DialogueText: All right, but you don't know what you're diluting.
I appreciate the restraint you're showing.
That's what I like to hear.
Say, this is pretty good. I like the way you prepare coffee, Yūbari.
I've gotten pretty darn good at it. It pays to be awake for disappointment.
Yūbari, come on. Don't beat yourself up. The cowboys never did that. They were tough ruffians.
I'm done beating myself up, Kanchou. People get snookered by mirages and snake oil. You dive into the bottom of a cup every time that happens, eventually you don't crawl back out.
Then what's got you down?
The world, Kanchou, and the people running it. That's what governments are made of. That's what our command structure is made of.
As long as that's true, we move as fast as our slowest commanding officer.
Maybe they need some of your coffee.
Maybe they need to see this front for themselves.
Hmm, the cantaloupe is missing. Yūbari must have eaten it.
Ieh! Nuh I dint.
Yūbari, is your mouth full of food right now?
*GULP* No way.
I see the empty rinds right over there.
I didn't leave those there. The sailor who cleans these rooms every day did.
Sure he did.
Kanchou... have you ever thought about what you might do after the war is over?

Fields.MenuText: No, not really.
I think about it every day.
This war won't ever be over.

Fields.DialogueText: If we win... no, when we win, I hope you have a plan. You can't fight for the rest of your life, you know.
But you're undecided? I guess no one needs to decide right now.
Yes, it will. Once we finally defeat these Funayūrei.
What about you? Do you have any plans?
Well, you're human. You can go back to the land.
What about your dreams to go to America? To explore the world?
I'll leave the frontier where it is. Turns out it looks just the same as anywhere once you get there.
@BATTLE
Me... a Kami like me isn't built for peace. Try and turn me into a museum ship and I'll sink myself. There's always a fight somewhere.
Now, blasting these Funayūrei from our waters... that's a difference I can make.
*ALARM*
Go on, then. Get it out of your system.
YEE-HAW!
... Did I do it right, Kanchou?
The American crew would be proud.
@BATTLE
Yatta! No one takes out the Funayūrei like we do. They tried riding into our town, but we weren't about to let them take it without a fight.
POW! We showed them who's boss. But we won't be safe long. This ocean is wild. There are always beasts out there to wrangle.
Yūbari, is that you making all that noise?
Ahh! Kanchou, did you listen to all of that?

Fields.MenuText: It sure was inspiring.
Listen to all of what?
Enough to get a laugh.

Fields.DialogueText: Looks like that spark hasn't guttered out completely. And it's spreading!
Good. You didn't hear me do anything. I didn't talk like a cowboy. Not at all.
You need to read more, Kanchou. You'll understand.
I came to tell you that the supply ship's intact, Yūbari.
Why didn't they signal us before?
Their radio's down. They flagged us to explain the situation. They're delivering medicine and food on a route that's been closed to civilian shipping.
It's crazy.
I'll say. But--
But it's the right thing to do.
Well, it's our problem now.
Just what they were waiting for. Their perseverance is about to pay off.
The sea is quiet today. And not in a good way.
We haven't seen any Morganas in a while.
Our last battle feels like a lifetime ago. Do you think they've all disappeared?

Fields.MenuText: Hahaha... no.
They could have retreated.
It's entirely possible. They appeared suddenly. They can disappear suddenly.

Fields.DialogueText: I was joking too. But it gets less and less funny the more I think about it.
It wouldn't be the first time. They're monsters, but they're strategic monsters.
A girl can dream.
Well we should use this time to...
Is that smoke on the horizon? Quick, hand me the binoculars.
Take them, Kanchou. I don't need them. Hmm...
There's smoke, all right. Looks as if some Funayūrei have chased down a supply ship.
What were they doing here without an escort?
Mukankei. We fight them here and now.
We're not breaking formation. We're en route to--
*ALARM*
Looks as if we have our own Funayūrei to see to. But I'm not letting another one go, Kanchou.
@BATTLE
Kanchou, we have to save those civilians.
Taking on a horde that size would put our own crew in unnecessary danger.

Fields.MenuText: Why? Because it's what the cowboys would have done?

Fields.DialogueText: It doesn't matter. They no longer exist.
So why ride in on a white horse to a losing battle?
I've been around for a while, Kanchou. I know there's good and bad in this world.
There's no moving you, is there?
I always get my man.
I'll signal the rest of the formation. We live or die with the outcome.
@BATTLE
Countless Kami have faced worse odds and won!

Fields.MenuText: I'm not going to lose you.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, Kanchou, you will. One day. And when you do, you ought to be proud of the reason why.

Fields.MenuText: You're not countless Kami.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right. I'm stronger.
Everything I believe in tells me to be good. Even if it's hard. Even if it's crazy. Even if what's bad looks invincible.
The heroes I believed in aren't real. But what they fought for can be, if only we fight for it.
Out of the question. There's no distress signal.
That doesn't worry you more?
Good enough for me.
They're putting up one hell of a fight!
We have to draw the Funayūrei away from the ship.
Kanchou - do you think if we move in and engage, the supply ship will be able to get away from the fighting?

Fields.MenuText: Smart idea, Yūbari.
We can try it.
And go where?

Fields.DialogueText: If we force them on the defensive, that puts their plans on hold.
The Funayūrei are self-centered. They'll fire back at us before anything else.
Away from the immediate area. Funayūrei are territorial. They'll fight each other for prey, but they'll fight a common enemy before they go for a kill.
Where'd you come up with your strategy?
Lots of places. Watching the Americans work. Rescue missions after the Kantō quake and when China heated up.
We'll draw them away for now and see where that gets us.
Into the sunset or up on Boot Hill.
@BATTLE
They're single-minded in pursuit of their target. Can we do that?
They're also vengeful. And there's more of us than there are of those civilians. If it's death they want, we're their best option.
The innocents don't choose a life-or-death situation. We do. And it's our responsibility to choose life.
That starts by fighting the fight far away from those who can't fight back.
*ALARM*
They just don't let up, do they?
Those no-good, lily-livered varmints...
@BATTLE
Keikakudōri. Those Funayūrei are too angry at us to worry about bullying the supply ship.
It's not over yet.
No way, not by a long shot. We're going to have to do a quick draw against them.
A quick draw?
Like from the cowboy stories. We're going to lead them away, and when the time is right we challenge them to a free-for-all.

Fields.MenuText: Great plan, Yūbari.
High noon, eh?
Will it work?

Fields.DialogueText: Bit of a spur-of-the-moment idea. Sometimes those work best.
It's no O.K. Corral, but I'll take it.
I hope so. We don't have many other options at this point.
You think you're a good enough shot?
I'd be a better shot with a couple of pearl-handled pistols.
We'll see about those, Yūbari. You're doing great with what you've got.
The Navy put their best into me. That doesn't mean I can't surprise them.
Look, the Funayūrei are starting to flee. We'll have this battle wrapped up before we know it.
That was a solid strategy, Yūbari. Good job.
Well, it wouldn't have been a success without you and the rest of the crew by my side.
I think you really showed off the true spirit of the American West.
Did I?
Ruthless in a fight and tireless in compassion.
You think I'm a real, modern-era cowboy, now?

Fields.MenuText: Yes, down to your very core.
A real, ocean-based, modern-era cowboy.
You're something more.

Fields.DialogueText: Thanks, Kanchou. That means a lot to me.
It's a bit of a mouthful, but I'll take it!
Cruiser tech's a frontier like any other. I was built to tame it.
*ALARM*
Draw.
@BATTLE
When the time is right.
When will that be?
Instinct, Kanchou. A cowgirl's born with it.
And now we sail off into the sunset.
Except that there's too much cloud cover to see much of anything, and we are actually travelling north.
It's a metaphor, Kanchou. Don't you know that? All of these cowboy stories are. And the sunset represents closure.
So, what? Your story has reached its end?
This chapter of it.
What about your dreams of being a cowgirl? A lone gunslinger for justice?
I'm not giving up on those. Even if they're based on stories, I'll just have to make them real in my own way.
I can't wait to see you get there.
Really? You want to see... does that mean you want to travel with me?
You sure you're coming? We're compadres now, you realize that, don't you?
We're a team, Yūbari.
Yes! I'm going to make some coffee... I hope you like yours strong.

Fields.MenuText: You know, a Belle can't go it alone. She needs a captain and crew.
If you're the one making it, Yūbari, I do.

Fields.DialogueText: I've got a few in mind.
I'll make sure you keep up, Kanchou. I've got so much more to show you.
